issue.title: Individual Authentication breaks builds when using SPA templates
issue.body:

If I build a SPA based project and try to directly run it via `dotnet myproject.dll` or `./myproject ` I get NullReferenceException regardless of configuration (Debug | Release).
however, simply running the project via `dotnet run` works no issue

I've made a git repo with the projects I found effected, https://github.com/henrikse55/dotnet-spa-problems
There is no modifications done to the projects, the commands I've run to reproduce this myself:

[Build project]
1. dotnet new angular -o AngularSpa -au Individual
2. cd AngularSpa
3. dotnet build -c Debug
4. dotnet bin/Debug/net5.0/AngularSpa.dll

5. curl -v -k https://localhost:5001

issue.title: Revert "Disconnect circuit on 'beforeunload' event"

labels.name: Servicing-approved
labels.description: Shiproom has approved the issue

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
**Description**

This PR reverts a change that was introduced in #23224 to ensure that circuits are not disconnected when protocol-based links (e.g. `mailto:` and `tel:`) are clicked or a download is programmatically triggered. This PR also:

- Adds E2E tests for newly-identified customer scenarios
- Adds an JavaScript API to give customers the flexibility to disconnect Blazor circuits whenever they want

**Customer Impact**

This change was made in response to [customer feedback](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/25724) that a recent bug fix broke important scenarios for users. Without this change, customer applications that use protocol-based links or programmatic downloads would break.

**Regression**

This is a regression from Blazor Server 3.1.

**Risk**

The risk of this change is low:

- New end-to-end tests were added for the discovered scenarios
- Behavior was reverted to what we shipped in 3.1 which is understood by users
- API was provided for users who want control over when disconnect call is made

comment.body:
Any updates?

Thanks in advance

issue.title: "There is no event handler associated with this event" when an element is focused out

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

milestone.title: Next sprint planning
milestone.description: This milestone is used to track the issues we plan to consider taking as part of our next milestone, within current release.

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
An error is thrown:
>  Error: System.ArgumentException: There is no event handler associated with this event. EventId: '3'. (Parameter 'eventHandlerId')

when an element with focusout handler is removed from the DOM in a blazor wasm app (both 3.1 and 5.0).

### To Reproduce
1. Clone the https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout repository
2. Set the [TestNet5Wasm.Server](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/tree/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Server) as a startup project. 
> **Note:** In order to test the 3.1 version of wasm, use the [TestNet31Wasm.Server](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/tree/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet31Wasm)
3. Run the app (Ctrl + F5)
4. On the `Index.razor` page, click on `item 2` that has [@onfocusout](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/blob/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Client/Pages/Index.razor#L8) handler

> **Note:** The main logic is part of the [Index.razor](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/blob/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Client/Pages/Index.razor) page only and the [script.js](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/blob/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Client/wwwroot/script.js) file.

### Exceptions (if any)
> Error: System.ArgumentException: There is no event handler associated with this event. EventId: '3'. (Parameter 'eventHandlerId')

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version 3.1, 5.0 RC1
- Include the output of `dotnet --info`
- The IDE (VS / VS Code/ VS4Mac) you're running on, and it's version

### Additional context
A similar problem is marked to be fixed in multiple cases like:
 https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/17926
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/21241
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/21366
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/21874#issuecomment-632814894

but the problem is still reproducible in both the 3.1 and 5.0 versions.

comment.body: @SteveSandersonMS I've failed to create a minimal repro thus far. I've put a couple hours into it. Every simple scenario I create seems to work, so I've been unable to isolate the exact problem here. I can provide you with access to the repo, if you'd like, otherwise I'll try and take another stab at this sometime this month by stripping away functionality until the problem disappears, rather than trying to recreate something simple.

issue.title: useLayoutEffect in ssr
issue.body:
Hi, I do not understand the situation with this hook a bit. I use this hook to perform the animation synchronously with the state update, if I use useEffect, then I have jumps in the animation, because the animation library does not have time to start. Also, the documentation states that useLayoutEffect runs on the same phase as componentDidMount (that is, on the client side), and here my server issues complaints to me about my code. Why is that?

https://codesandbox.io/s/oo47nj9mk9

_Originally posted by @dimensi in https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/14596#issuecomment-466023638_

comment.body: Giving this another bump, as `useIsomorphicLayoutEffect` gets confused by Jest+JSDOM as @markerikson pointed out. We either have the test logs polluted by this error warning or have a separate maintenance overhead with separated test classes for SSR, annotated with the alternative jest node environment.

issue.title: Bug With Incorrect Rendering In Blazor Web Assembly 5.0 When Using The @Key Directive

labels.name: :heavy_check_mark: Resolution: Answered
labels.description: Resolved because the question asked by the original author has been answered.

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
With Blazor Web Assembly 5.0, I have found that if a parent component uses the @Key directive, then even if the child component ShouldRender returns false, its rerendering it anyways.

However, I found that I still had to use the @Key in the parent component otherwise, there can be a case where it does not refresh properly.

There needs to be a way where if ShouldRender is false but there was a key directive, it still won't render because of the overrided method.  Let me know if I need to produce a sample to post on github to explain further.

issue.title: Server-side Blazor with Cookie authentication: no redirect to login if child route is requested

labels.name: :heavy_check_mark: Resolution: Answered
labels.description: Resolved because the question asked by the original author has been answered.

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Cookie authentication is configured in a server-side Blazor app as follows:

```
        public void ConfigureServices(IServiceCollection services)
        {
            services.AddAuthentication(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme).AddCookie(
                options =>
                    {
                        options.LoginPath = "/login";
                    });
            services.AddAuthorization(options =>
                {
                    options.DefaultPolicy =
                        new AuthorizationPolicyBuilder(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
                            .RequireAuthenticatedUser().Build();
                });

            services.AddRazorPages();
            services.AddServerSideBlazor();
            // ...
        }
```

```
public void Configure(IApplicationBuilder app, IWebHostEnvironment env)
        {
            // ...
            app.UseAuthentication();
            app.UseAuthorization();

            app.UseEndpoints(endpoints =>
                {
                    var authorizeAttribute = new AuthorizeAttribute
                                             {
                                                 AuthenticationSchemes =
                                                     CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme
                                             };

                    endpoints.MapRazorPages().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapBlazorHub().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");
            });
        }
```

Then the app is started from Visual Studio. If the first request to the application goes to `https://localhost:5001/` and the user is not authenticated, a redirect will happen to the login page. But if the first request to the application for instance goes to `https://localhost:5001/counter` and the user is not authenticated, no redirect is happening and the app's main layout will be displayed, but instead of the page content the message *Not authorized* is shown.

**What should happen?**

Users that are not authorized should always be redirected to the login page, regardless of the page they are requesting first.

**Disclaimer:** it is not clear if this behavior is caused by configuring the app wrongly or by a bug in the framework.

### To Reproduce

Repo with sample code and detailed steps to reproduce in README:
https://github.com/adiessl/BlazorSampleApp

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version
`net5.0`

issue.title: Server-side Blazor with Cookie authentication: no redirect to login if child route is requested

labels.name: :heavy_check_mark: Resolution: Answered
labels.description: Resolved because the question asked by the original author has been answered.

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Cookie authentication is configured in a server-side Blazor app as follows:

```
        public void ConfigureServices(IServiceCollection services)
        {
            services.AddAuthentication(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme).AddCookie(
                options =>
                    {
                        options.LoginPath = "/login";
                    });
            services.AddAuthorization(options =>
                {
                    options.DefaultPolicy =
                        new AuthorizationPolicyBuilder(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
                            .RequireAuthenticatedUser().Build();
                });

            services.AddRazorPages();
            services.AddServerSideBlazor();
            // ...
        }
```

```
public void Configure(IApplicationBuilder app, IWebHostEnvironment env)
        {
            // ...
            app.UseAuthentication();
            app.UseAuthorization();

            app.UseEndpoints(endpoints =>
                {
                    var authorizeAttribute = new AuthorizeAttribute
                                             {
                                                 AuthenticationSchemes =
                                                     CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme
                                             };

                    endpoints.MapRazorPages().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapBlazorHub().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");
            });
        }
```

Then the app is started from Visual Studio. If the first request to the application goes to `https://localhost:5001/` and the user is not authenticated, a redirect will happen to the login page. But if the first request to the application for instance goes to `https://localhost:5001/counter` and the user is not authenticated, no redirect is happening and the app's main layout will be displayed, but instead of the page content the message *Not authorized* is shown.

**What should happen?**

Users that are not authorized should always be redirected to the login page, regardless of the page they are requesting first.

**Disclaimer:** it is not clear if this behavior is caused by configuring the app wrongly or by a bug in the framework.

### To Reproduce

Repo with sample code and detailed steps to reproduce in README:
https://github.com/adiessl/BlazorSampleApp

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version
`net5.0`
- Include the output of `dotnet --info`

issue.body:
I've read the documentation about the SHA checking for assets, and anyway I didn't change anything on my generated project.
I always need to Ctrl-F5 to load the new version of the client application after deploying it to an Azure App Service.  
The documentation says that even if the SHA checks are on, the server can still decide to send different caching informations to the client. In my case, I didn't modify at all the default App Service that is created through 'normal' CLI calls, so I don't know if this behaviour is normal, or if there's some bug.  
Eventually, can anyone point me to how to configure the Azure App Service to let the SHA checking in the Blazor application to take control?  
Thanks in advance

comment.body:
@javiercn Thanks for the link, I never checked that tab in the developer tools.  
Unfortunately each time I have slightly different results. To test what is said in the given document, I deployed a new version (the last was from yesterday).  
I didn't hit Ctrl-F5 yet, only browsing the page, and reloading with F5, so I'm seeing the old version (even after closing all the chrome browsers I have open on my machine.  
The page is loaded (apparently) correctly (in the old version), but with these errors in the console, that I never had previously:  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63686917/100460110-f1018a80-30c6-11eb-941a-db609234d699.png)
Moreover, the application tab shows this:  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63686917/100460247-2ad29100-30c7-11eb-8d86-6c328443830e.png)
The '32' in the number of errors is incrementing each time I reload (by 4 each time), but the errors on fetches apparently are much more, each time.  
It's true that I'm seeing myself that the service-worker is in yesterday version, and it's just my client application dll to be modified, but I still cannot imagine how to have the browser automatically load the new version...

issue.title: Server-side Blazor with Cookie authentication: no redirect to login if child route is requested

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Cookie authentication is configured in a server-side Blazor app as follows:

```
        public void ConfigureServices(IServiceCollection services)
        {
            services.AddAuthentication(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme).AddCookie(
                options =>
                    {
                        options.LoginPath = "/login";
                    });
            services.AddAuthorization(options =>
                {
                    options.DefaultPolicy =
                        new AuthorizationPolicyBuilder(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
                            .RequireAuthenticatedUser().Build();
                });

            services.AddRazorPages();
            services.AddServerSideBlazor();
            // ...
        }
```

```
public void Configure(IApplicationBuilder app, IWebHostEnvironment env)
        {
            // ...
            app.UseAuthentication();
            app.UseAuthorization();

            app.UseEndpoints(endpoints =>
                {
                    var authorizeAttribute = new AuthorizeAttribute
                                             {
                                                 AuthenticationSchemes =
                                                     CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme
                                             };

                    endpoints.MapRazorPages().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapBlazorHub().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");
            });
        }
```

Then the app is started from Visual Studio. If the first request to the application goes to `https://localhost:5001/` and the user is not authenticated, a redirect will happen to the login page. But if the first request to the application for instance goes to `https://localhost:5001/counter` and the user is not authenticated, no redirect is happening and the app's main layout will be displayed, but instead of the page content the message *Not authorized* is shown.

**What should happen?**

Users that are not authorized should always be redirected to the login page, regardless of the page they are requesting first.

**Disclaimer:** it is not clear if this behavior is caused by configuring the app wrongly or by a bug in the framework.

### To Reproduce

Repo with sample code and detailed steps to reproduce in README:
https://github.com/adiessl/BlazorSampleApp

- ASP.NET Core version
`net5.0`

issue.title: proj.Views.dll not included in single file publish of Blazor project

labels.name: :heavy_check_mark: Resolution: Answered
labels.description: Resolved because the question asked by the original author has been answered.

labels.name: area-mvc
labels.description: Includes: MVC, Razor, Localization, CORS, most templates

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
After upgrading a Blazor 3.1 project to net50, single file publish seems broken. There is one extra dll generated, called <projectname>.Views.dll. It is just 18kB and only contains a type called Pages__Host. If this dll is removed, the project fails at runtime with something like "Cannot find the fallback endpoint specified by route values: { page: /_Host, area: }"

### To Reproduce
I have not managed to repro it outside our project. I hope you will know where I can look to find a solution for this. If you have some pointers I might be able to create a small repro that I can share. Maybe there is some code that needs to be updated in Startup etc when migrating Blazor 3.1 to 5.0 related to this.
I also found a test case here: https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/0d8d4e709cdfbc13e7fc7797dbbc1b46ddeb7c33/src/Razor/Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor/integrationtests/BuildWithComponents31IntegrationTest.cs#L18
This seem related, and it says something about Blazor 3.1 which I migrated from. But from the test it looks like the Views.dll file should exist and contain this Pages__Host type, but what I don't understand is why it is not included in the single file published.

### Exceptions (if any)
Note, this is only if I remove the Views.dll, which I understand I can't. But just wanted to see if it was used since I published for single file.
fail: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Diagnostics.ExceptionHandlerMiddleware[1]

      An unhandled exception has occurred while executing the request.

      System.InvalidOperationException: Cannot find the fallback endpoint specified by route values: { page: /_Host, area:  }.

         at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.RazorPages.Infrastructure.DynamicPageEndpointMatcherPolicy.ApplyAsync(HttpContext httpContext, CandidateSet candidates)

         at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Diagnostics.ExceptionHandlerMiddleware.<Invoke>g__Awaited|6_0(ExceptionHandlerMiddleware middleware, HttpContext context, Task task)

comment.body:
@maloo I'm not familiar with the details of why we decided to go this way. I'll let @pranavkm comment since he was directly involved on it, but I'm sure they thought about the options and came to the conclusion that this was a reasonable trade-off.

I understand your desire to have a truly single executable, if that is what you want, you can probably do something in MSBuild to make it happen (I have no idea what).

We might do improvements in this area in 6.0, however that's not something we support in 5.0.

I'll let @pranavkm add his comments here from now on, since I'm not an expert in this area and don't have much else to add.

issue.title: Unable to debug Blazor hosted webassembly 3.2.0 from Visual Studio 2019 16.6.2

labels.name: :heavy_check_mark: Resolution: Fixed
labels.description: The bug or enhancement requested in this issue has been checked-in!

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
<!--

More information on our issue management policies can be found here: https://aka.ms/aspnet/issue-policies

Please keep in mind that the GitHub issue tracker is not intended as a general support forum, but for reporting **non-security** bugs and feature requests.

If you believe you have an issue that affects the SECURITY of the platform, please do NOT create an issue and instead email your issue details to secure@microsoft.com. Your report may be eligible for our [bug bounty](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/msrc/bounty-dot-net-core) but ONLY if it is reported through email.
For other types of questions, consider using [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com).

-->

### Describe the bug
I have Visual Studio 2019 16.6.2 installed, along with the .NET Core 3.1.301 SDK and all the necessary Blazor templates.

If I create a brand new Blazor WebAssmbly application, I can run it from Visual Studio by pressing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>F5</kbd> and it opens a new tab on my active browser window and starts fine.  

But when I press <kbd>F5</kbd>, a new, separate browser window is opened instead of a tab in my main browser window (which is a pity), but the page remains at `about:blank` for a while until an error message appears in Visual Studio:

```
Failed to launch debug adapter.  Additional information may be available in the output window.

Unable to launch browser: 
"Could not open wss://localhost:5001/_framework/debug/ws-proxy?browser=wsAFFlocalhostA50821FdevtoolsFbrowserFceed3b95-58ac-470a-b10c-5d139cfd7117": timeout after 60000ms
```

Whether the Blazor WebAssembly application is "Hosted" or not doesn't make a difference.

I've followed the steps in the [Enforce HTTPS in ASP.NET Core](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/aspnet/core/security/enforcing-ssl?view=aspnetcore-3.1&tabs=visual-studio#troubleshoot-certificate-problems), but that made no difference either.

If, while waiting for the `about:blank` window to crash, I manually open the client side url on a browser tab, the app loads and the debugger breakpoints are hit.
During the short while before it goes on to crash, if I hit <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>D</kbd> I *always* get the following error:

```
Unable to find debuggable browser tab
Could not get a list of browser tabs from http://127.0.0.1:9222/json. Ensure your browser is running with debugging enabled.

Resolution

If you are using Microsoft Edge (80+) for your development, follow these instructions:
Press Win+R and enter the following:

msedge --remote-debugging-port=9222 --user-data-dir="C:\Users\[my_username]\AppData\Local\Temp\blazor-edge-debug" --no-first-run https://localhost:44372/
```

I get this each and every time, no matter how often I run the command (having closed all browser instances, rebooted, etc)

This happens in both Edge 84 (Edgium) and Chrome.

I should be able to create a new Blazor WebAssembly app and hit <kbd>F5</kbd> on Visual Studio out of the box. What am I missing?



#### =============== UPDATE ==================
I've just tried using "old Edge" (EdgeHtml) and Firefox as the debug browser in Visual Studio, and both work as expected (meaning that the application at least starts up when pressing <kbd>F5</kbd>). The problem apears to be both Chromium-based browsers then...

#### =============== UPDATE 2 ==================
Removing the `IIS Express` section from `launchSettings.json` on the Server project allows VS 2019 to start Kestrel up and that does load the Blazor Wasm app on a new browser window. <kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>D</kbd> still fails with `Unable to find debuggable browser tab`, though.


### To Reproduce
<!--
We ❤ code! Point us to a minimalistic repro project hosted in a GitHub repo.
For a repro project, create a new ASP.NET Core project using the template of your your choice, apply the minimum required code to result in the issue you're observing.

We will close this issue if:
- the repro project you share with us is complex. We can't investigate custom projects, so don't point us to such, please.
- if we will not be able to repro the behavior you're reporting
-->
Just create a fresh Blazor WebAssembly from Visual Studio and press <kbd>F5</kbd>

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core 3.1.3
- Visual Studio 2019 16.6.2
- Windows 10 (1909)

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

milestone.title: Next sprint planning
milestone.description: This milestone is used to track the issues we plan to consider taking as part of our next milestone, within current release.

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
An error is thrown:
>  Error: System.ArgumentException: There is no event handler associated with this event. EventId: '3'. (Parameter 'eventHandlerId')

when an element with focusout handler is removed from the DOM in a blazor wasm app (both 3.1 and 5.0).

### To Reproduce
1. Clone the https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout repository
2. Set the [TestNet5Wasm.Server](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/tree/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Server) as a startup project. 
> **Note:** In order to test the 3.1 version of wasm, use the [TestNet31Wasm.Server](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/tree/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet31Wasm)
3. Run the app (Ctrl + F5)
4. On the `Index.razor` page, click on `item 2` that has [@onfocusout](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/blob/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Client/Pages/Index.razor#L8) handler

> **Note:** The main logic is part of the [Index.razor](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/blob/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Client/Pages/Index.razor) page only and the [script.js](https://github.com/Stamo-Gochev/blazor-net5-wasm-focusout/blob/master/TestNet5Wasm/TestNet5Wasm/Client/wwwroot/script.js) file.

### Exceptions (if any)
> Error: System.ArgumentException: There is no event handler associated with this event. EventId: '3'. (Parameter 'eventHandlerId')

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version 3.1, 5.0 RC1
- Include the output of `dotnet --info`
- The IDE (VS / VS Code/ VS4Mac) you're running on, and it's version

### Additional context
A similar problem is marked to be fixed in multiple cases like:
 https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/17926
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/21241
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/21366
https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/21874#issuecomment-632814894

but the problem is still reproducible in both the 3.1 and 5.0 versions.

comment.body: Can anyone confirm which release version, will this fix be included?

### Describe the bug
After upgrading a Blazor 3.1 project to net50, single file publish seems broken. There is one extra dll generated, called <projectname>.Views.dll. It is just 18kB and only contains a type called Pages__Host. If this dll is removed, the project fails at runtime with something like "Cannot find the fallback endpoint specified by route values: { page: /_Host, area: }"

### To Reproduce
I have not managed to repro it outside our project. I hope you will know where I can look to find a solution for this. If you have some pointers I might be able to create a small repro that I can share. Maybe there is some code that needs to be updated in Startup etc when migrating Blazor 3.1 to 5.0 related to this.
I also found a test case here: https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/0d8d4e709cdfbc13e7fc7797dbbc1b46ddeb7c33/src/Razor/Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor/integrationtests/BuildWithComponents31IntegrationTest.cs#L18
This seem related, and it says something about Blazor 3.1 which I migrated from. But from the test it looks like the Views.dll file should exist and contain this Pages__Host type, but what I don't understand is why it is not included in the single file published.

### Exceptions (if any)
Note, this is only if I remove the Views.dll, which I understand I can't. But just wanted to see if it was used since I published for single file.

comment.body: For wwwroot I just use the embedded file provider, I assume the same way Blazor main files are provided without being in wwwroot. But you can't make a Blazer server dll available for client download, it makes no sense. If you could not make it part of the new memory mapped single file solution, fine, that is just like the native dlls. But then you should make sure you include it in the "3.1 extract option" added in 5.0 to handle these special files that can't use direct mapping or merging. The option I mean is the new IncludeNativeLibrariesForSelfExtract. This option is exactly to handle this case. And even if your file is not native, it falls between the gap of this new option and merging in the single exe. So I can only see two options here:

comment.body:
@maloo the way single file publish works in .NET Core 3.1 is significantly different to how it works in .NET 5.0 and as a result of that we could not make the Views.dll part of the bundle.

I'm not sure what you are doing to make the `wwwroot` files included in the bundle while making it work, since they are not included by default, but you could try and do the same thing for the Views assembly.

issue.title: FileStreamResult does not handle files which are actively being written to well

labels.name: area-mvc
labels.description: Includes: MVC, Razor, Localization, CORS, most templates

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
Returning a `FileStreamResult` for a file which is actively being written to without range processing causes an `InvalidOperationException` in Kestrel.

There's a [StackOverflow comment](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54886750/how-to-serve-a-file-in-asp-net-core-while-its-still-being-written#comment96543334_54886750) which describes the issue well.

"
The problem is [FileStreamExecutorBase](https://github.com/aspnet/AspNetCore/blob/master/src/Mvc/Mvc.Core/src/Infrastructure/FileResultExecutorBase.cs) -- it sets the `Content-Length` header once, based on the length of the file as it is then, but if the request is not a range request, it invokes `StreamCopyOperation.CopyToAsync` without passing a length, so the stream is copied wholly. There are multiple ways around this: a PR for this, deriving from `FileStream` to fixate the length (not trivial!), or plugging in a new `IActionResultExecutor<FileStreamResult>` (somehow). – Jeroen Mostert Feb 26 '19 
"

### To Reproduce
I'm personally running into this by trying to return an `application/octet-stream` `FileStreamResult` of an active Serilog file for the program, but theoretically this should happen with any file being actively written to.

### Exceptions (if any)

issue.title: FileStreamResult does not handle files which are actively being written to well

labels.name: area-mvc
labels.description: Includes: MVC, Razor, Localization, CORS, most templates

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
Returning a `FileStreamResult` for a file which is actively being written to without range processing causes an `InvalidOperationException` in Kestrel.

There's a [StackOverflow comment](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54886750/how-to-serve-a-file-in-asp-net-core-while-its-still-being-written#comment96543334_54886750) which describes the issue well.

There are multiple ways around this: a PR for this, deriving from `FileStream` to fixate the length (not trivial!), or plugging in a new `IActionResultExecutor<FileStreamResult>` (somehow). – Jeroen Mostert Feb 26 '19

comment.body:
@Cyberboss thanks for contacting us.

This is not an scenario FielStreamResult is designed for and we don't plan to add this type of functionality in the near future unless we hear significant feedback about it.

labels.name: area-mvc

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
After upgrading a Blazor 3.1 project to net50, single file publish seems broken. There is one extra dll generated, called <projectname>.Views.dll. It is just 18kB and only contains a type called Pages__Host. If this dll is removed, the project fails at runtime with something like "Cannot find the fallback endpoint specified by route values: { page: /_Host, area: }"

### To Reproduce
I have not managed to repro it outside our project. I hope you will know where I can look to find a solution for this. If you have some pointers I might be able to create a small repro that I can share. Maybe there is some code that needs to be updated in Startup etc when migrating Blazor 3.1 to 5.0 related to this.
I also found a test case here: https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/0d8d4e709cdfbc13e7fc7797dbbc1b46ddeb7c33/src/Razor/Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor/integrationtests/BuildWithComponents31IntegrationTest.cs#L18
This seem related, and it says something about Blazor 3.1 which I migrated from. But from the test it looks like the Views.dll file should exist and contain this Pages__Host type, but what I don't understand is why it is not included in the single file published.

### Exceptions (if any)
Note, this is only if I remove the Views.dll, which I understand I can't. But just wanted to see if it was used since I published for single file.

issue.title: Generic Type parameter of ActionResult doesn't enforce strict type.

labels.name: area-mvc
labels.description: Includes: MVC, Razor, Localization, CORS, most templates

issue.body:
<!--

More information on our issue management policies can be found here: https://aka.ms/aspnet/issue-policies

Please keep in mind that the GitHub issue tracker is not intended as a general support forum, but for reporting **non-security** bugs and feature requests.

If you believe you have an issue that affects the SECURITY of the platform, please do NOT create an issue and instead email your issue details to secure@microsoft.com. Your report may be eligible for our [bug bounty](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/msrc/bounty-dot-net-core) but ONLY if it is reported through email.
For other types of questions, consider using [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com).

-->

### Describe the bug
When you set a Type on the Generic Parameter of ActionResult and return any type other than that - it would still proceed.
I mean, should this be expected? or not? or am I implementing web APIs incorrectly?

### To Reproduce
<!--
We ❤ code! Point us to a minimalistic repro project hosted in a GitHub repo.
For a repro project, create a new ASP.NET Core project using the template of your your choice, apply the minimum required code to result in the issue you're observing.

We will close this issue if:
- the repro project you share with us is complex. We can't investigate custom projects, so don't point us to such, please.
- if we will not be able to repro the behavior you're reporting
-->
1. `dotnet new webapi`
2. Create a controller with a method that ActionResult is used with a generic parameter and return a different type.
```
class Sample {}

[HttpGet("{id}")]
public ActionResult<Sample> GetCourt(int id)
{
    return Ok(1);
}
```

### Exceptions (if any)
<!-- 
Include the exception you get when facing this issue
-->

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version - **5.0** but this actually happens on different versions
- Include the output of `dotnet --info` - down below
- The IDE (VS / VS Code/ VS4Mac) you're running on, and it's version - VS19

comment.body:
@javiercn thanks for contacting us.

I believe the that ActionResult<T> is only used for the purposes of being able to express the return type on the method signature.

Other action results convert implicitly to `ActionResult<T>` so I believe the behavior is by design and we don't intend to enforce it, since we want to be able to let you return alternative object types in some cases, like when there is an error.

/cc: @pranavkm  can confirm.

issue.title: Browser still using cached versions of application after re-deployment (Blazor WebAssembly app on Azure App Service)

labels.name: Needs: Attention :wave:
labels.description: This issue needs the attention of a contributor.

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
I've read the documentation about the SHA checking for assets, and anyway I didn't change anything on my generated project.
I always need to Ctrl-F5 to load the new version of the client application after deploying it to an Azure App Service.  
The documentation says that even if the SHA checks are on, the server can still decide to send different caching informations to the client. In my case, I didn't modify at all the default App Service that is created through 'normal' CLI calls, so I don't know if this behaviour is normal, or if there's some bug.  
Eventually, can anyone point me to how to configure the Azure App Service to let the SHA checking in the Blazor application to take control?  
Thanks in advance

comment.body: @ABIOLI-COM we think this is by design. Check [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/blazor/progressive-web-app?view=aspnetcore-5.0&tabs=visual-studio#update-completion-after-user-navigation-away-from-app) for details

issue.title: Server-side Blazor with Cookie authentication: no redirect to login if child route is requested
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Cookie authentication is configured in a server-side Blazor app as follows:

```
        public void ConfigureServices(IServiceCollection services)
        {
            services.AddAuthentication(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme).AddCookie(
                options =>
                    {
                        options.LoginPath = "/login";
                    });
            services.AddAuthorization(options =>
                {
                    options.DefaultPolicy =
                        new AuthorizationPolicyBuilder(CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme)
                            .RequireAuthenticatedUser().Build();
                });

            services.AddRazorPages();
            services.AddServerSideBlazor();
            // ...
        }
```

```
public void Configure(IApplicationBuilder app, IWebHostEnvironment env)
        {
            // ...
            app.UseAuthentication();
            app.UseAuthorization();

            app.UseEndpoints(endpoints =>
                {
                    var authorizeAttribute = new AuthorizeAttribute
                                             {
                                                 AuthenticationSchemes =
                                                     CookieAuthenticationDefaults.AuthenticationScheme
                                             };

                    endpoints.MapRazorPages().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapBlazorHub().RequireAuthorization(authorizeAttribute);
                    endpoints.MapFallbackToPage("/_Host");
            });
        }
```

Then the app is started from Visual Studio. If the first request to the application goes to `https://localhost:5001/` and the user is not authenticated, a redirect will happen to the login page. But if the first request to the application for instance goes to `https://localhost:5001/counter` and the user is not authenticated, no redirect is happening and the app's main layout will be displayed, but instead of the page content the message *Not authorized* is shown.

**What should happen?**

Users that are not authorized should always be redirected to the login page, regardless of the page they are requesting first.

**Disclaimer:** it is not clear if this behavior is caused by configuring the app wrongly or by a bug in the framework.

### To Reproduce

Repo with sample code and detailed steps to reproduce in README:
https://github.com/adiessl/BlazorSampleApp

- ASP.NET Core version
`net5.0`

issue.title: Layout sections in Blazor

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

milestone.title: Next sprint planning
milestone.description: This milestone is used to track the issues we plan to consider taking as part of our next milestone, within current release.

issue.body:
Basically the same as https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/10131 which has been closed in in favour of #10452 which was in turn closed in favour of #10450 (influencing the `<head>`). 

Having the ability to embed content from the page in the layout in more than one placeholder is a common need. A typical use case is to display the page name in the "header" of the application which is usually defined in the layout. Another use case is to display personalised content for the currently logged user.

A lot of other technologies support this feature and I think it would be a great addition to Blazor. A few examples:

- ASP.NET WebForms has [ContentPlaceholder](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/web-forms/overview/older-versions-getting-started/master-pages/multiple-contentplaceholders-and-default-content-cs)
- ASP.NET MVC has [sections](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/mvc/views/layout?view=aspnetcore-5.0)
- Web Pages also have sections
- Angular has [router outlets](https://angular.io/api/router/RouterOutlet#description)
- React Router also [supports multiple components](https://gist.github.com/kitdemonio/33be59d4ab597f2679e83d68e1b63842)

Thank you for your consideration!

comment.body:
Thanks for contacting us.
We're moving this issue to the `Next sprint planning` milestone for future evaluation / consideration. We will evaluate the request when we are planning the work for the next milestone. To learn more about what to expect next and how this issue will be handled you can read more about our triage process [here](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/master/docs/TriageProcess.md).

issue.title: .Net5.0 not respecting StaticWebAssetBasePath on publish of Blazor WASM project

labels.name: Done
labels.description: This issue has been fixed

labels.name: Servicing-consider
labels.description: Shiproom approval is required for the issue

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

labels.name: area-mvc
labels.description: Includes: MVC, Razor, Localization, CORS, most templates

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
After upgrading to .Net5.0  I noticed that when publishing (`dotnet publish`) a Blazor WASM project the **StaticWebAssetBasePath** is not taken into account.
The files inside `wwwroot` are not put in the specified base folder.
However, when the project is run, the framework files are correctly located.

I'm following this documentation about `<StaticWebAssetBasePath>`
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/blazor/host-and-deploy/webassembly?view=aspnetcore-5.0#hosted-deployment-with-multiple-blazor-webassembly-apps

### To Reproduce
Run:  `dotnet new blazorwasm`
Open the `.csproj` file
Add `<StaticWebAssetBasePath>test</StaticWebAssetBasePath>` inside `<PropertyGroup>`
Save & Run: `dotnet publish`
Look at the content of: `bin\Debug\net5.0\publish\wwwroot`

**Current result**: Most files are incorrectly located in `wwwroot` and some files are inside `wwwroot\test`
**Expected result**: All files (framework,css,...) should be inside `wwwroot\test`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1290874/98964028-53a73380-24d6-11eb-823e-bb182a8a508f.png)

I get the expected result when running the same steps with .NetCore 3.1 (`dotnet new blazorwasm -f netcoreapp3.1`) 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1290874/98964394-bef10580-24d6-11eb-9079-227e810f695b.png)



### Further technical details
- .Net 5.0
```
dotnet --info
.NET SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   5.0.100
 Commit:    5044b93829

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.19041
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\5.0.100\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 5.0.0
  Commit:  cf258a14b7

.NET SDKs installed:
  5.0.100 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
```
I ran the commands on the command line.

issue.title: Bug: setState in onFocus breaks onChange event in Concurrent Mode
issue.body:
Using concurrent mode on `0.0.0-experimental-7f28234f8` makes `<Checkbox/>` from Baseweb stop firing `onChange` events.

Baseweb is a popular set of React components that reflects real world usage patterns such that maybe it should work right off the bat with Concurrent mode. Feel free to close if you're confident this is a userland problem and not a framework problem, but I think this may indicate an incompatibility between Concurrent Mode and Legacy mode that isn't documented or warned about it if so, because `<Checkbox/>` isn't doing anything too fancy and doesn't use deprecated APIs or warn when rendered in Strict mode or Concurrent mode. I feel like that means it's supposed to just work, right? 

React version: `0.0.0-experimental-7f28234f8`

## Steps To Reproduce

1. Click a `<Checkbox/>` rendered using Legacy mode and note that it checks
2. Click a `<Checkbox/>` rendered using Concurrent mode and note that it does not check 

See issue here: https://baseweb-react-concurrent-checkbox.stackblitz.io (edit here: https://stackblitz.com/edit/baseweb-react-concurrent-checkbox?file=src/index.js)

I've been trying to debug and haven't found any smoking guns yet, but there are some interesting tidbits I can share that might allude to if this is a React bug or a Baseweb bug:
 - `onFocus` and `onBlur` handlers fire just fine on both modes 
 - `<Checkbox/>` doesn't use `findDOMNode` or other deprecated APIs in Concurrent mode as best I can tell. No warnings are fired when rendering it in Strict mode or Concurrent + Strict mode
 - focusing the `Checkbox` by tabbing and pressing space checks and fires the `onChange` handler on both Legacy and Concurrent mode
 - Wide swaths of the rest of baseweb work just fine in Concurrent mode

See https://github.com/uber/baseweb/issues/3476 for the `baseweb` issue.

issue.title: Blazor (WASM) AAD authentication fails: getAccessToken returns undefined

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

issue.body:
Upgrading to .NET 5 and my Azure AD authentication has broken. The bug ultimately exists inside AuthenticationService.ts.

```
Unhandled exception rendering component:  An exception occurred executing JS interop: The JSON value could not be converted to Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication.InternalAccessTokenResult. Path: $ | LineNumber: 0 | BytePositionInLine: 4.. See InnerException for more details. 
 Microsoft.JSInterop.JSException: An exception occurred executing JS interop: The JSON value could not be converted to Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication.InternalAccessTokenResult. Path: $ | LineNumber: 0 | BytePositionInLine: 4.. See InnerException for more details.
 ---> System.Text.Json.JsonException: The JSON value could not be converted to Microsoft.AspNetCore.Components.WebAssembly.Authentication.InternalAccessTokenResult. Path: $ | LineNumber: 0 | BytePositionInLine: 4.
```

Last meaningful line is the RemoteAuthenticationService. So, it's trying to parse some JSON returned from an InvokeJS call.

Specifically, what it's trying to do is invoke `AuthenticationService.getAccessToken` (line 149 in `RemoteAuthenticationService`).

However, this code is returning `{ status: 'success', r: undefined }`. Undefined is not valid JSON, hence it's serializing to something, and breaking.

So why is it doing this? Beacuse `getTokenCore` tries to call `getAccount` and returns null if it is unset. And it is unset: because nobody has logged in yet! `getAccessToken` then continues on, blissfully unaware, because it only returns 'requiredRedirect' if there's an exception.

So: the AAD authentication is broken if it's attempted to be used before anybody has logged on. This breaks the Blazor WASM AAD tutorial example of using `AuthorizationMessageHandler` to trap missing authentication and redirect. It means you must authenticate up front, manually, instead of allowing authentication requests to flow naturally only when authentication is required.

comment.body:
@wasabii thanks for contacting us.

Could you share more details about your environment?
Can you make sure that the AuthenticationService.js is not being incorrectly cached and it's using the 3.1 version?
Did you update your application registration in the portal to use the new SPA platform instead of Web?

issue.title: Fix MaxRequestBodySize in IIS

labels.name: area-servers
labels.description: Includes: Kestrel, IIS, HttpAbstractions, libuv, AzureIntegration, ANCM

labels.name: tell-mode
labels.description: Indicates a PR which is being merged during tell-mode

issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/24555
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/22950
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/22834

- When checking the MaxRequestBodySize, we never updated it with the value from IIS.
- Change int to uint to allow uint.MaxValue
- Remove 30MB constant in managed code as the value already defaults to 30MB from native and we always set the value in managed from native.

# Description
There is two bug in the IIS MaxRequestBodySize feature which made it so it wouldn't read the value from IIS correctly and couldn't accept a value larger than Int.MaxValue. This made the middleware too restrictive, causing people difficulties who were trying to increase the limit.

# Customer Impact

Fixes the feature by reading the correct value from native as well as accepting UInt.MaxValue, matching the max limit in IIS.

# Regression?

No

# Risk

Low. This fixes an already existing feature and people who were working around it today wouldn't be affected.

comment.body: I want to upload a file of size greater than UInt.MaxValue. Is there any way I can do that? I get a 413.1- Request entity too large error when uploading file larger than 4gb in asp.net core.

    at Loader.getModuleJob (node:internal/modules/esm/loader:229:28)
    at ModuleWrap.<anonymous> (node:internal/modules/esm/module_job:51:40)
    at link (node:internal/modules/esm/module_job:50:36) {
  code: 'ERR_MODULE_NOT_FOUND'
}
```
```
> npx webpack-cli D:\repos\jsx\index.mjs
[webpack-cli] Compilation finished
assets by status 264 bytes [cached] 1 asset
./index.mjs 64 bytes [built] [code generated]

ERROR in ./index.mjs 1:0-41
Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'react/jsx-runtime' in 'D:\repos\jsx'
Did you mean 'jsx-runtime.js'?
BREAKING CHANGE: The request 'react/jsx-runtime' failed to resolve only because it was resolved as fully specified
(probably because the origin is a '*.mjs' file or a '*.js' file where the package.json contains '"type": "module"').
The extension in the request is mandatory for it to be fully specified.
Add the extension to the request.

webpack 5.4.0 compiled with 1 error in 150 ms
npm ERR! code 1
```

## The expected behavior
No issues importing `react/jsx-runtime` with no file extensions.

I can think of two solutions:
- Fix babel, typescript, and all the other tools that automatically add the import to add the file extension.
  - That ship has sailed though, I don't think this is right thing to do.
- Add the `exports` field in react's `package.json`.
  - This could also open the door to supporting prod/dev builds without depending on `process.env.NODE_ENV` for bundlers.
  - More discussion here: https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/11503#issuecomment-717589904
  - https://nodejs.org/dist/latest/docs/api/packages.html
  - https://webpack.js.org/guides/package-exports/

comment.body:
I'm reposting [this comment of mine](https://github.com/babel/babel/issues/12210#issuecomment-734806233) from the Babel's tracker but I adjust it slightly to fit better here. You can read it here or in the linked thread.

--- 

Adding extensions in the emitted code is being problematic for a couple of reasons and I believe that it should be avoided. I understand that it's unfortunate that things break right now because of it - but node's semantics are *very* new. The ESM support in node has been released just this month - so it's understandable that some packages are not yet ready in full for it.

The solution for this would be indeed to add `exports` map like in this PR: https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/20304 . It was already a great gesture from the React team to ship runtimes for all~ React versions. I suppose they could add exports map in a similar fashion to all of them, just to avoid confusion etc. It makes sense given how many users they have but it's not up to me to decide about this.

As to the current webpack's situation - just don't use `.mjs` for now. If you rename your file to `.js` then webpack will gladly resolve the `react/jsx-runtime` entrypoint. You just don't have to opt-into the new node's semantics right away and just give time for this issue here to be resolved.

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
Hosting Blazor WebAssembly app with enabling PWA in Azure Storage static website, browser don't display PWA install tip.
But if host in Azure Storage container is working.

### To Reproduce
1. Create Blazor WebAssembly app in VS2019 , enable PWA
1. Publish this app
1. Create an Azure Storage (for example name is "staticweb"), create a container (for example "mywasm"), modify published index.html, change `<base href="/" />` to `<base href="/mywasm/" />`
1. Upload published contents into this container
1. Access index.html (for example "https://staticweb.blob.core.windows.net/mywasm/index.html"), you can see PWA install tip
1. If you create an ARM account with static website, don't modify base path, upload published contents into $web container, access "https://myblazor.z7.web.core.windows.net/", you also cannot see PWA install tip

### Exceptions (if any)
N/A

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version 5.0

comment.body:
@javiercn it does happen for new projects also.
The issue seems to be this:
If the previous debug session doesn't terminate the browser window, and you go to launch a new debug session - I see this error.
If I close the previous window, then launch it works.
Why doesn't the previous window close correctly when you terminate the previous debug session? In my case, if the blazor app has some form of startup error etc.

The screen shot shows the browser window hanging round from first debug session which launched correctly but didn't terminate correctly, and in second tab is the second attempt as launching a debug session, a new window opened and I see the error reported and the debug session terminates, leaving the new orphaned tab. If I close all tabs and start from scratch it works.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3176632/100440601-111c5400-309d-11eb-81ef-4b45517d9b07.png)

issue.title: Bug: Run exceptions in Chrome Extension
issue.body:
React version: 17.0.1 ## Steps To Reproduce 1. use create-react-app initialize project 2. coding 3. yarn build 4. enter the second input tab 5. input no focus and no redraw 6. but debug the element value is changed Link to code example: ``` import React from 'react'; import styles from './App.module.less'; import Switch from '../../components/Switch'; import produce, { Draft } from 'immer'; const initialState: globalSetting = { globalEnable: false, proxys: [] }; const reducer = produce((state: Draft, action: { type: string, payload?: any }) => { switch (action.type) { case 'globalEnableChange': state.globalEnable = !!action.payload; return case 'ruleSwitchChange': state.proxys[action.payload!.ruleIndex].enable = action.payload!.val; return case 'ruleRegChange': state.proxys[action.payload!.ruleIndex].reg = action.payload!.val; return case 'ruleAddHost': state.proxys[action.payload].hosts.push({ domain: '', ip: '', enable: true }) return case 'ruleSubHost': state.proxys[action.payload!.ruleIndex].hosts.splice(action.payload!.hostIndex, 1); return case 'hostSwitchChange': state.proxys[action.payload!.ruleIndex].hosts[action.payload!.hostIndex].enable = action.payload!.val; return case 'addRule': state.proxys.push({ enable: true, reg: '', hosts: [] }) return case 'delRule': state.proxys.splice(action.payload, 1); return case 'hostDomainChange': state.proxys[action.payload!.ruleIndex].hosts[action.payload!.hostIndex].domain = action.payload!.val; return case 'hostIpChange': state.proxys[action.payload!.ruleIndex].hosts[action.payload!.hostIndex].ip = action.payload!.val; return case 'submit': localStorage.setItem('globalEnable', state.globalEnable ? 'true' : 'false'); localStorage.setItem('proxys', JSON.stringify(state.proxys)); chrome.extension.getBackgroundPage()?.proxySubmit(); return default: throw new Error(); } }) function initializer() { const proxyStr = localStorage.getItem('proxys'); let proxys: Rule[] = []; if (proxyStr) { proxys = JSON.parse(proxyStr); } const globalEnableStr = localStorage.getItem('globalEnable'); let globalEnable: boolean = false; if (globalEnableStr && globalEnableStr === 'true') { globalEnable = true; } return { globalEnable, proxys } } function App () { const [state, dispatch] = React.useReducer(reducer, initialState, initializer); return
扩展开关： dispatch({ type: 'globalEnableChange', payload: val })} />
{ state.proxys.map((rule, ruleIndex, array) => { return
dispatch({ type: 'ruleSwitchChange', payload: { val, ruleIndex} })} /> dispatch({ type: 'ruleRegChange', payload: { val: val.target.value, ruleIndex } })} />
{ rule.hosts.map((host, hostIndex) => { return
dispatch({ type: 'hostSwitchChange', payload: { val, ruleIndex, hostIndex } })} /> dispatch({ type: 'hostDomainChange', payload: {val: val.target.value, ruleIndex, hostIndex} })}/> dispatch({ type: 'hostIpChange', payload: {val: val.target.value, ruleIndex, hostIndex} })}/>
}) }
}) }
} export default App; ``` https://github.com/MrQinYQ/proxy-extenstion ## The current behavior ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16348159/100434545-9cb2d680-30d7-11eb-8c8f-3d95556930c8.png) ## The expected behavior ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16348159/100434851-15199780-30d8-11eb-8693-b46912bdc675.png)

issue.title: Bug: Strange lines in the page
issue.body:
When chrome devtools is opened, some strange lines appear in the page and disappear after disable&enable the react extension.
I'm wondering if there are some bugs on react extension.
Win10x64 Chrome 87.0.4280.66
[Chrome issue 83155766](https://support.google.com/chrome/thread/83155766)
![img](https://storage.googleapis.com/support-forums-api/attachment/thread-83155766-2167922176753088865.jpg)

comment.body:
What you're seeing are re-renders that the extension is highlighting. You can disable this by opening the browser devtools, switching to the "Components" tab (from react-devtools), open settings, switch to "General" and uncheck "Highlight updates when components render":

![devtools-rerender](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12292047/100435256-fb5b5e80-309d-11eb-8166-494283d923ad.gif)

labels.name: Status: Unconfirmed
labels.description: A potential issue that we haven't yet confirmed as a bug

comment.body:
Sorry you're having issues.

However, this issue is a result of `@types/react` or rather TypeScript which is not released from this repository.

In the TypeScript playground your code is working fine (https://www.typescriptlang.org/play?#code/JYWwDg9gTgLgBAJQKYEMDG8BmUIjgcilQ3wG4AoGATzCTgAUcwBnOAXjjnOXRgDoAIkhgpgAGyQATABIAVALIAZRhBYAeHhj5ylAQRgwowAEYBXGEmZqdigcABuAUQkgkAOxgA+ADRcbdpxd3LyA) so this is likely an issue with your build setup.

You'll find better help by asking on stackoverflow or the [TypeScript discord server](https://discord.com/invite/typescript).

issue.title: Question: Is there a experimental release based on 17 stable?
issue.body:
Apologize for posting a question here, as I don't think it should be posted on StackOverflow.

I've noticed the latest experimental release is `0.0.0-experimental-4ead6b530`, which seems to be based on an alpha version of React. Is there an experimental release based on 17 stable, or am I mistaken, and there's no difference between these two versions?

Also, are both next and experimental release channels guaranteed to be newer than the stable channel?

Thanks!

issue.title: Feature Request: useComponent Hook
issue.body:
I would like to propose a feature to be implemented in react based on this library https://github.com/myckhel/react-use-component

The `react-use-component` was created to limit the use of memoised callback hooks and to create `Object Oriented` functional `Components`.

I would like the react team to look into the concept of this `API` and consider its benefits to the amazing `React` framework. 

Thanks for your review.

comment.body:
It seems the proposal is to have a hook similar to the React class component model. The purpose of the hooks was to solve these problems. >**- It’s hard to reuse stateful logic between components** >**- Complex components become hard to understand** https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-intro.html#its-hard-to-reuse-stateful-logic-between-components
>* Huge components that are hard to refactor and test. >* Duplicated logic between different components and lifecycle methods. >* Complex patterns like render props and higher-order components. > >We think Hooks are our best shot at solving all of these problems. Hooks let us organize the logic inside a component into reusable isolated units: https://dev.to/dan_abramov/making-sense-of-react-hooks-2eib The `useComponent` proposal does not seem to fit the problem the hooks was intended to solve.

issue.title: Blazor serverside cannot read large file streams from client

labels.name: area-blazor
labels.description: Includes: Blazor, Razor Components

milestone.title: Next sprint planning
milestone.description: This milestone is used to track the issues we plan to consider taking as part of our next milestone, within current release.

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
I want to be able to read files from client browsers using blazor server-side. Using the <InputFile/> component, I choose some test file. If the file size is more than 2-3 GB, I cannot read it.
I am not trying to upload the whole file. You can see that from the sample page.


### To Reproduce
The clean template with just 1 file added
https://github.com/xPucTu4/BlazorUploadBug

You can create new blazor-server project and just add that file:
https://github.com/xPucTu4/BlazorUploadBug/blob/main/BlazorUploadBug/Pages/Upload.razor

### Exceptions (if any)
With file size of about 4GB:
Sometimes JSException with message "[object ProgressEvent]"
With file size of about 3GB there is no exception or any indications of errors.

issue.title: Mvc.Testing: Create WebApplication from subdirectory of AppContext.BaseDirectory

labels.name: Needs: Author Feedback
labels.description: The author of this issue needs to respond in order for us to continue investigating this issue.

labels.name: area-mvc
labels.description: Includes: MVC, Razor, Localization, CORS, most templates

issue.body:
I am trying to create unit tests for an ASP.NET Core app using the WebApplicationFactory. The twist is, that the web application is located in a subdirectory of the _\bin_ folder where the unit tests are compiled to, say _\bin\WebApp_.

Now, the WebApplicationFactory will check if the WebApp.deps.json file is present (which it is, in _\bin\WebApp_). However, it will look for this file not in the directory of the assembly containing the WebApp.Startup class, but instead in AppContext.BaseDirectory (see [EnsureDeps](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/84b77de14c161803b36978bf498b8a6db8b95471/src/Mvc/Mvc.Testing/src/WebApplicationFactory.cs#L290)), which in my case is _\bin_. In summary:
- _\bin\WebApp\WebApp.deps.json_ does exist
- but WebApplicationFactory is looking for _\bin\WebApp.deps.json_

Maybe I am missing some workaround for the issue, but if not, it would be nice if WebApplicationFactory could start apps outside the AppContext.BaseDirectory folder.

comment.body:
@javiercn here is a minimal  [repro project](https://github.com/ThorstenReichert/WebApplicationFactoryRepro) for this issue.

It consists of two solutions, one ASP NET Core WebApp and a unit test solution. To repro the issue, you can run
```
dotnet build .\WebApplicationFactoryRepro.WebApp
dotnet test .\WebApplicationFactoryRepro.Test
```

I recognize that this setup might look quite strange. In my use case, I have actually two gRPC services, that need to cooperate (and that is what I would like to test). Each service comes in via a nuget package, that extracts the service into a subfolder of $(OutputPath) (this is modelled here by having the WebApp solution build directly into _\bin\WebApp_ and the Test solution build into _\bin_).

issue.title: LDAP support in negotiate authentication fails with "connection reset by peer"

labels.name: area-security
labels.description: Includes: Security, OAuth, OIDC

issue.body:
When using LDAP under Linux, so that one can have group membership in negotiate authentication, the connection to the LDAP server (domain controller) fails with error  "connection reset by peer".

The reason is that the connection to the LDAP server is made when the server application starts up. But if the connection is idle, it is closed. Thus the error when an query is made.

Either the connection should be retried after receiving ECONNRESET error, or tcp keepalive should be enabled.

In addition, the connection is unencrypted, therefore ldap user and password are sent in cleartext. It should be possible to enable TLS in LdapSettings.

Of course, the right thing to do would be to parse the group membership data from the Kerberos ticket.

comment.body:
> > Of course, the right thing to do would be to parse the group membership data from the Kerberos ticket.
> 
> The APIs we use don't give us access to the raw kerberos ticket or role data, and the ticket doesn't always contain the roles. Hence the LDAP lookup.

Yes we can have access to the PAC authorization data, with the function gss_get_name_attribute with attribute name "urn:mspac:". For instance, the [Samba code does that](https://git.samba.org/?p=samba.git;a=blob;f=auth/kerberos/gssapi_pac.c).

This is the solution with MIT Kerberos. (Heimdal Kerberos is better at many things, and had integrated PAC support earlier, but for now let us stay focused in solving the issue)

issue.title: Bug: React's batching makes state comparison checks unreliable

labels.name: Status: Unconfirmed
labels.description: A potential issue that we haven't yet confirmed as a bug

issue.body:
It seems that in some situations React's batching makes comparison to change in state unreliable.
In the provided example, focus/blur handlers produce different outcomes:
- when triggered via **tabbing**
- vs. when **manually focusing on keydown**

React version: 17.0.0

## Steps To Reproduce

1. Open the provided codesandbox
2. Focus the 2 inputs back and forth by tabbing
3. Note the `onChange` logs correspond to the updates and are in sync with the UI
4. Now instead, focus an input then press the **down arrow** to programmatically focus back and forth between the 2 inputs
5. Note the `onChange` logs are now wrong and inconsistent with the UI (initially `true` and then `false` forever)

Link to code example: https://codesandbox.io/s/react-staleness-ishfn?file=/src/App.js

## The current behavior

### When tabbing through this is the output I get:

onChange `true`
onChange `false`
onChange `true`
onChange `false`
onChange `true`
onChange `false`

### When pressing arrow down to focus the inputs back and forth I get:

onChange `true`
onChange `false`
onChange `false`
onChange `false`
onChange `false`
onChange `false`

> Note that if you check the "Prevent React from batching updates?" checkbox, both examples behave the same. The only difference is that in this case, we wrap the `.focus()` calls in a `setTimeout()` to avoid batching.

## The expected behavior

We would expect the 2 examples to behave the same.

comment.body:
> The question is, why does it matter? The terminal result is still the same.

Yep, but we needed to know if a change had occurred. Our mistake here was to assume that the state would be an up to date reference to "change" when of course, that's not reliable given the way render closures work. 

The first thing we had tried was to use a `ref` here which obviously worked but we had convinced ourselves we were overlooking something here. Moral of the story is to not doubt ourselves so much next time 😅 

I think we can close this. Thanks for the speedy reply @sebmarkbage !

issue.title: Feedback on useEffect depndencies change error

labels.name: Resolution: Stale
labels.description: Automatically closed due to inactivity

issue.body:
Some feedback on `useEffect`

**What is the current behavior?**

I am using `useEffect` to load details on a set of users that are kept in props.

I want to minimize loading and there are situations where the array of users (and the actual user objects) are recreated but really they refer to the same identities.

So I do

```
const userIds = users.map(u => id)
useEffect(() => {
  if(!userIds.length)
    return
  ...load more stuff by querying endpoints about these ids and set state..
}, userIds)
```

aand I run into a warning

> The final argument passed to useEffect changed size between renders. The order and size of this array must remain constant

which to me is...kinda the point, is it not? I understand if we don't want to do a deep comparison in the dependencies, but if the dependencies themselves change...well that seems straightforward, run the effect. 

I know that I can do `[userIds.join(' '])` in this case, but that seems like just extra work for no reason and really anti-intuitive. And ends up doing the same exact thing but with extra steps! 

To be clear, what I'm proposing is removing [this whole block here](https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/master/packages/react-reconciler/src/ReactFiberHooks.js#L308) and replacing it with

```
if (nextDeps.length !== prevDeps.length)
  return false
```

As far as I can tell, this warning serves no real purpose and makes the use case outlined above awkward to deal with

comment.body:
> > Yup - if you look at the code, it would seem that you can replace
> > ```
> >     if (nextDeps.length !== prevDeps.length) {
> >       warning(
> >         false,
> >         'The final argument passed to %s changed size between renders. The ' +
> >           'order and size of this array must remain constant.\n\n' +
> >           'Previous: %s\n' +
> >           'Incoming: %s',
> >         currentHookNameInDev,
> >         `[${prevDeps.join(', ')}]`,
> >         `[${nextDeps.join(', ')}]`,
> >       );
> >     }
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> > with
> > ```
> > if (nextDeps.length !== prevDeps.length)
> >   return false
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> > and then my use case would be supported _and_ there would be no other negative effects.
> > So I'm asking the team what is the purpose of this warning and also why not change it?
> 
> We should do this. Please re-open.

This doesn't solve your problem though, since `users` length is the same. You can consider putting users in the dep array.

issue.title: Blazor - Designing API for complex component with nested properties
issue.body:
I`m investigating how to design a complex component API with nested properties

Let's imagine we are creating a grid component with columns. We have a set of predefined columns, other columns are autogenerated based on source structure. Also, I have bindings to the properties of nested components.

<GridComponent ItemsSource="@Source" AutoGenerateColumns="AddNew">
    <Columns>
        <GridColumn Member="Test" SortMode="@SortMode" />
        <GridColumn Member="Test2" DataType="@DataType"/>
    </Columns>
</GridComponent>

I need to compose inner components with root component properties to obtain markup for prerendering. So I need to obtain the whole component structure before render. How to do it?

Other platforms I`m familiar like Winforms or WPF have a System.Component.Model.ISupportInitialize concept for transactional component initialing however I can't find analogs in Blazor.

What is the recommended way to design such API?

issue.title: SignInManager has hard coded Schemes

labels.name: area-identity
labels.description: Includes: Identity and providers

labels.name: multi-tenancy
labels.description: Issues based in multi-tenancy

issue.body:
## Summary

The SignInManager has hard coded Schemes which are very difficult to change even if you subclass the SignInManager. It would be a relatively easy change to allow inheritors to change these hard coded schemes to what they want. It also seems that the `IAuthenticationSchemeProvider` is only used to resolve external schemes but perhaps it could/should be used to `GetDefaultAuthenticateSchemeAsync()` instead of using the hard coded `IdentityConstants.ApplicationScheme` ? (maybe that's not what `GetDefaultAuthenticateSchemeAsync()` is intended for so not too sure on that one)

## Motivation and goals

Like many things in aspnetcore, it is opinionated that things that are global are the way they need to be but this opinion doesn't cater for having multi-tenancy application setup. For example, the Umbraco CMS has back office Users and front-end Members. They don't share the same data storage/services at all because they are entirely different. You can log in as a back office user separately than a front-end member. There will be different cookies and authentication schemes working in tandem. Further, for front-end Umbraco members we don't want to get in the way of the end-user's potential default aspnetcore membership setup. This can happen because the Umbraco CMS doesn't get in the way of any existing website implementation. So in this scenario there can be up to 3x SignInManager (2 subclassed so they are unique services in DI). 

We have this working but the amount of code to replace the hard coded schemes is pretty huge where it would be pretty easy to just have virtual properties to override for these hard coded scheme names, or have another service injected that returns these schemes. 

* IdentityConstants.ApplicationScheme
* IdentityConstants.ExternalScheme
* IdentityConstants.TwoFactorUserIdScheme
* IdentityConstants.TwoFactorRememberMeScheme

It would be super easy to create a PR with these things as virtual properties to override and happy to do that but let me know what you think. I realize this isn't a typical type of thing that most websites do but there's a lot of hoops we've had to jump through to make things work that are globally unchangeable that could be very easily made more flexible (i.e. https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/22217)

comment.body:
@blowdart thanks for the reply. Yep I agree, have been shoehorning things around identity for years 😂 I realize it's not designed for multi-tenancy but people are still doing such things which either requires some zany work arounds or just copying code. Small updates to make parts more flexible (i.e. not hard coding schemes) would be immediately helpful since it seems like any redesign and implementation about multitenancy is a long way away.

For any folks interested, if you want to have a SignInManager with custom schemes to replace the hard coded ones, you will need to override and copy the code from the source for these methods (it's not quite all of the SignInManager but it's a good chunk):

* `GetTwoFactorAuthenticationUserAsync` & `TwoFactorRecoveryCodeSignInAsync` 
  * copy/modify the private method `RetrieveTwoFactorInfoAsync` containing the hard coded schemes
* `TwoFactorSignInAsync` 
  * copy/modify the private methods `RetrieveTwoFactorInfoAsync`, `DoTwoFactorSignInAsync` containing the hard coded schemes
  * copy the private class `TwoFactorAuthenticationInfo` since its not public
* `IsSignedIn`
* `RefreshSignInAsync`
* `SignInWithClaimsAsync`
* `SignOutAsync`
* `IsTwoFactorClientRememberedAsync`
* `RememberTwoFactorClientAsync`
  * copy/modify the private method `StoreRememberClient` containing the hard coded scheme
* `ForgetTwoFactorClientAsync`
* `GetExternalLoginInfoAsync`
* `SignInOrTwoFactorAsync` 
   * copy/modify the private method `IsTfaEnabled` since it's not public
  * copy/modify the private method `StoreTwoFactorInfo` containing the hard coded scheme

Just being able to have properties to override these schemes would save all of this code duplication.
